title: Does Gladwell admit there are masters of certain skills that do not need 10,000 hours? - Quora

response.answer_text: The “10,000 hours” idea stems from a literal translation of a Chinese saying. In Chinese, they say “10,000” to mean “a lot.” It’s a metaphor. So everyone should just stop chasing this 10,000 hour number. Malcolm Gladwell's 10,000 Hour Rule is Proven Bunk “Does Gladwell admit there are masters of certain skills that do not need 10,000 hours?” But, back to Gladwell, his understanding of the rule is based on cognitively demanding fields. So, yes. In this article, Gladwell acknowledges that 10,000 hours is the average. So, the Chinese were right: we’re talking about a lot of hours. If you’re looking for an approximate order of magnitude, sure, let’s go with 10,000 (4 to be precise), but to think that expertise requires close to 10,000 hours? Hogwash. This may or may not be relevant to you: If you want to be good at something, practice every day, evaluate your results carefully, embrace incremental gains, don’t take your failures personally, and have an idea where you want to go. Focus inside your practice; don’t focus outside at some arbitrary number of hours spent practising.
